An adrenal incidentaloma was detected in a patient who underwent evaluation for renalcalculi. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?

options.A: The majority of these adrenal masses are functional tumours
options.B: The likelihood of the adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma is independent of thesize of the mass
options.D: The only indication for biopsy of this adrenal mass is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis

questions.explanation: The only indication for an adrenal gland biopsy is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis.An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentallydetected on imaging performed for indications other than evaluation for adrenal disease. Themajority of these lesions are non-functional tumours i.e. benign. The likelihood of an adrenalmass being an adrenocortical carcinoma increases with the size of the mass (25% chance if size>4 cm).Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as functional and non-functional. Non-functionalincidentalomas <4cm are managed conservatively with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If>4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.Note: An adrenal mass should never be biopsied until a pheochromocytoma has beenbiochemically excluded.

questions.question: 350A patient being evaluated for primary aldosteronism underwent selective adrenal venoussampling. A comparison of the samples obtained from both the adrenal veins showed asignificant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio. What is the preferred line of treatmentfor this patient?

options.C: Medical treatment with spironolactone and supplemental antihypertensives

questions.explanation: During selective adrenal vein sampling, a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio onone side indicates unilateral hyperaldosteronism. In this case, unilateral laparoscopicadrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.Primary hyperaldosteronism (PHA) is characterized by hypersecretion of aldosterone withsuppressed plasma renin levels (due to the negative feedback). The most frequent cause of PHA isunilateral adenoma.CT or MRI is used to detect the tumour. In a patient with bilateral micronodular hyperplasia,there could be a unilateral non-functioning tumour. Selective adrenal vein sampling can be doneto differentiate between unilateral and bilateral disease.Conservative management with 3-6 months of MRI surveillance is done in non-functional adrenaltumours of < 4cm.Medical management is done in patients with bilateral disease, the commonly implementedtherapeutic approach is treatment with spironolactone and antihypertensive medication.Surgical management is done in unilateral and asymmetrical bilateral disease by unilaterallaparoscopic adrenalectomy. A subtotal resection can be considered in the case of a typical singleConn's adenoma. However, it is not superior to unilateral adrenalectomy.

options.A: Femoral vein→IVC→right renal vein→right adrenal vein
options.B: Femoral vein→IVC→left renal vein→left adrenal vein
options.D: Femoral vein→IVC→left gonadal vein→left adrenal vein

questions.explanation: The correct sequence encountered during sequential venous sampling is femoral vein→IVC→leftrenal vein→left adrenal vein.On the right side, the order is femoral vein→IVC→right adrenal vein.357Selective venous samplingRight adrenal glandRightadrenalveinLeft adrenal glandLeftadrenalveinRight renal veinLeft renal veinInferiorvena cavaRight femoralveinCatheterCOMARROW

questions.question: A patient was found to have an elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol level and elevated ACTH. Onadministration of high-dose dexamethasone, ACTH levels were suppressed. MRI of thepituitary gland shows no enlargement. What is the next best step?

options.A: CT scan of the chest and abdomen
options.B: CT scan/ MRI to assess the adrenals
options.C: Venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus

questions.explanation: The given scenario of elevated ACTH levels that respond to high-dose dexamethasone suppressiontest is indicative of a pituitary source of hypercortisolism. Since the MRI pituitary is inconclusive,the next best step is to perform a venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus.The stepwise approach to hypercortisolism is as follows:• Confirmation: This includes 2 steps:• Tests to detect hypercortisolism (° 2 abnormal test results):••Midnight salivary or serum cortisol24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion•Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST)•Low dose DST• Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome:• Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test• Identifying the source• Localizing the lesion358Diagnostic algorithm to determinethe cause of Cushing's syndromeDiagnosis of Cushing's syndrome confirmedDetermine cause: ACTH levels=5 pg/mLACTH-independent15 pg/mLACTH-dependentCT abdomenAdrenocortical adenomaAdrenocortical carcinomaBilateral adrenal hyperplasia- MRI brain- High dose dexamethasonesuppression test (DST)- GRH stimulation test- MRI brain-pituitary mass seen- High dose DST test –- CRH50% cortisol suppressionstimulation test --5096 cortisol increasePituitary adenoma->2 at baseline■=3 within 5-10 min ofCRH administrationPituitary adenomaHif tests are inconclusive(1.e. failure of any criteriamentioned in box A).Inferior petrosalsinus samplingCalculate ACTH gradient{Petrosal sinus ACTH levels +Peripheral blood ACTH levels)› MARROW2 at baselineImaging (CT, MRI, PETsoans of the chest.abdomen, neck)Paraneoplastic cauSOS

questions.question: A patient with Cushing's syndrome presents with deep vein thrombosis. Which of thefollowing mechanisms do not contribute to this?
questions.explanation: Increased factor V does not contribute to the risk of thromboembolic complications like DVT in apatient with Cushing's Syndrome.There is increased factor VIII, vWF, and decreased fibrinolysis in Cushing's syndrome patientswhich causes an increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications.Patients with Cushing's Syndrome are at a greater risk of acquiring hospital-acquired infection,thromboembolic and myocardial complications. Therefore, prophylactic anticoagulants andantibiotics constitute an essential component of pre-operative management.

questions.question: Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in all of the following conditions except

options.C: Unlocalised primary tumour of the adrenals

questions.explanation: Unilateral adrenalectomy is done in adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4cm.Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in:• Bilateral ACTH-independent disease•Ectopic ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome• Irresectable or unlocalized primary tumorAdrenalectomy is done as a surgical measure in severe hypercortisolism or Cushing's disease. Theadrenalectomy can be unilateral or bilateral depending on whether the tumor autonomouslysecrete hormones that could have a detrimental effect on health or If the adrenal mass benign ormalignant.

questions.question: A 57-year-old male patient has undergone unilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's syndromeand you have been asked to start him on cortisol supplementation, post-surgery. What is therationale behind it?

options.A: Remaining adrenal gland has insufficient reserve
options.B: Contralateral adrenal gland is suppressed by prolonged cortisol over-secretion

questions.explanation: 359The rationale behind cortisol supplementation after the surgical removal of the adenoma is thatthere is suppression of the contralateral adrenal gland by the pre-operative elevated cortisollevels. This causes primary adrenal insufficiency.Patients undergoing unilateral adrenalectomy typically require exogenous steroids for up to ayear, which is usually the duration the remaining adrenal gland takes to recover adequatefunction. In bilateral adrenalectomy, steroids are required indefinitely, and patients may alsorequire mineralocorticoid replacement therapy.Option A: The remaining adrenal gland usually has sufficient reserve to maintain homeostasis.Option C: A deficiency of ACTH causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. However, the adrenalinsufficiency post adrenalectomy is primary i.e due to the hyposecretion of cortisol from the glanditself.Option D: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is a bilateral adrenal infarction associated withmeningococcal sepsis and is rapidly fatal unless immediately treated.

questions.question: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of new-onset hyperpigmentation of the skin.He had undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease 2 years ago. Which of thefollowing statements is not true regarding his current condition?

options.A: It is characterized by elevated ACTH
options.B: Glucocorticoid replacement has to be continued
options.D: Screening is done using brain MRI

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of new-onset hyperpigmentation post-adrenalectomy is suggestiveof Nelson's syndrome. The first-line and definitive management is surgical resection of thepituitary adenoma.Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is aprocedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitaryadenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increasesCRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of theoriginal pituitary tumor or formation of a new one.Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:• Hyperpigmentation• Excessive ACTH secretion• Corticotroph adenomaScreening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regularintervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. Theprimary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoidreplacement, as they do not produce cortisol.The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the needfor bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient admitted for evaluation of treatment-resistant hypertension andparoxysmal palpitations was found to have elevated metanephrines on urine screen. What isthe next best step in the clinical management of this patient?

options.A: Imaging study with an MRI scan
options.B: Medical pre-treatment with phenoxybenzamine followed by laparoscopic resection
options.C: Imaging study with a contrast CT scan

questions.explanation: In this scenario, the elevated urinary metanephrines point towards the diagnosis ofpheochromocytoma. Hence, the next best step is an MRI to localise the site of the tumour.MRI is preferred for the localization of pathologies because contrast media used for CT scans canprovoke paroxysms. Classically, pheochromocytomas show a 'Swiss cheese' configuration.123 Iodine-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) single-photon emission computed tomography(SPECT) is essential for the detection of multiple extra-adrenal tumours and metastases, but PETscan using FDG or DOPA is more sensitive in detecting metastatic foci.The image given below shows MRI (marked B and C) and high uptake on 123I-mIBG scintigraphy(marked D and E)ABCDELaparoscopic resection is now a routine in the treatment of pheochromocytoma.An α-adrenoreceptor blocker, phenoxybenzamine, is used pre-operatively to block excesscatecholamine and its consequences during surgery. ẞ-blocker is added if there is tachycardia orarrythmia.

questions.question: Germline mutations of which of the following genes is not associated with hereditarypheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation: Germline mutation in NF2 gene is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2, and not hereditarypheochromocytoma. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with NF1 germlinemutations.Pheochromocytomas can occur in isolation or can be associated with hereditary tumor syndromeswith the specific germline mutations such as:•Neurofibromatosis type 1 - mutation in NF1 gene361•Familial paraganglioma syndrome - mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunitB (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes• Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) - activating germline mutations of RETproto-oncogene• Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - mutations in VHL gene

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the thirdpostoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there isno sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of hypotension with no presence of bleeding and bilateraladrenalectomy is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused dueto sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to aprecipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenalhemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands. It presentswith non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain,hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominalemergency.Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitarypathology- lack of ACTH) or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH).Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency worldwide.Tuberculosis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in India.Adrenal crisis requires immediate intervention owing to its high mortality rate. Immediaterehydration is initiated with a saline infusion at 1 litre/hr with continuous cardiac monitoring.Glucocorticoid replacement is initiated with an initial bolus injection of hydrocortisone 100 mgfollowed by 200 mg over 24 hours, preferably by continuous infusion or alternatively by IV or IMinjections. Mineralocorticoid replacement is initiated once the daily dose of hydrocortisone hasbeen reduced to <50 mg, since hydrocortisone at higher doses provides sufficient stimulation ofmineralocorticoids.

questions.question: Neuroblastoma can originate in all of the following except
questions.explanation: Neuroblastoma does not originate in the adrenal cortex.Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours ariseduring fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. Therefore,tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:• Adrenal medulla most common site-• Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia•Sympathetic para ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl362Note: Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extradural) tumour in children andthe most common overall tumour in infants.

questions.question: A 2-year-old girl child with failure to thrive was found to have a palpable, firm, irregularabdominal mass that crossed the midline. CT revealed a calcified mass near the left kidneywhich on biopsy showed Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Which of the following is not trueregarding this condition?

options.A: 70% patients present with metastasis at diagnosis
options.B: Urine homovanillic acid is used for screening
options.C: Amplification of N-myc gene is a good prognostic factor
options.D: Abdominal mass is a common presentation of the condition

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of neuroblastoma and amplification of N-myc gene is anindicator of poor prognosis.Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla. Homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelicacid (VMA) are elevated in the urine of approximately 95% of patients and are used to diagnoseand monitor this tumor.Clinical features:• Abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)•• Periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbitalmetastases)•Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome• Hypertension - due to secretion of catecholaminesMetastatic disease is present in more than 70% of patients at presentation.Homer-WrightpseudorosettesImmatureganglion cellsHistopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas arecomposed of small, immature ganglion cells with dark nuclei. Typically, Homer-Wrightpseudorosettes can be found which are tumour cells concentrically arranged about a central spacefilled with neuropil.The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumour and chemotherapy.

questions.question: What is the most common presentation of adrenal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: 363The most common presentation in patients with adrenal carcinoma is Cushing's syndrome due toexcess cortisol.Patients with non-functioning tumours frequently complain of abdominal discomfort or back pain(large tumours).Mc Farlane classification is used for staging adrenal carcinoma. Treatment involves completeresection of tumour and chemotherapy.364
